title: Our Research
section: General properties of intra-specific size distributions
text:
General properties of intra-specific size distributions


Are there general rules that govern relatives abundances of small, medium and large fish in a population? Are these rules consistent across fish groups, habitats, temperature and geographic regions? And if so, can these rules be applied to quantify fishing and other impacts on fish populations?






Aims

We are using large datasets from underwater visual surveys, sampling and other sources to explore shapes of body size distributions across hundreds of fish species. Our results suggest that these distributions are relatively consistent across species ranging from 10cm to 1.5 meters in body size. This suggests that growth and mortality, which determine population and species size distributions, may also be constrained.
The next step is to assess spatial and temporal scales over which body size distributions become unpredictable and how the importance of life-history and environmental conditions in explaining the residual variation from the general patterns.

We are keen to test the generality of body size distributions across a much larger ranges of species and habitats, and across different data collection methods. For that we need individual size data from natural fish populations without much fishing pressure. If you would like to collaborate with us - get in touch.







Preprint: Temperature affects fish body sizes. Which sizes?

Mean, maximum, asymptotic, adult, maturation size are all different size measures and temperature may affect them differently.

title: Our Research
text:
Temperature impacts on fish sizes


Temperature has large impacts on fish sizes, both naturally and also through human induced climate change. However, it is still not clear how temperature might affect growth, size structure or mean sizes in natural populations and we use diverse data sources and simulations to explore that. 






Aims

Using underwater visual survey data from Reef Life Survey we show that mean lengths of fish in natural populations can either increase or decrease with temperature changes across space. This temperature driven change in mean length is very strong (3% change per 1C), which means that average fish length on the warm and cool edge of the fish distribution area can be up to 30% different. Moreover, global warming driven changes in average fish size through time are often qualitatively similar, but rate of change is nearly 10 times faster. But this raises many other questions, which we aim to answer below. 
Is the increase in mean size in warmer waters compatible with the temperature size rule, which states that in warmer conditions fish grow to smaller maturation sizes? 
Fish size distributions are shaped by rates of growth and mortality, and by using simulation modelling we can manipulate these two parameters to see how population mean and maximum size might change under different temperature conditions. Using these methods we can show that it is possible to get increasing population mean sizes, even though the maximum and asymptotic size may be declining, as predicted by the temperature size rule.



Major findings
For a full list of the impacts and outcomes of this research, see Resources.

title: Our Research
section: Using historical records to understand shifting baselines
text:
Using historical records to understand shifting baselines


Historical data helps us understand the cumulative impact of human activities and minimise the shifting baseline syndrome by estimating the degree to which human activities can alter marine fish populations and ecosystems. We aim to incorporate historical records (oral histories, photographs, newspaper articles, logbooks) for estimating past fish population size distributions at local and regional scales.
Examples of the use of historical sources to understand past fisheries dynamics: 





Chong-Montenegro C, Thurstan RH, Pandolfi JM (2022) Quantifying the historical development of recreational fisheries in Southeast Queensland, Australia. Mar Ecol Prog Ser 696:135-149. DOI: doi.org/10.3354/meps14138

title: Shane Richards
text:
Shane Richards

Title


Applying mathematical and statistical tools, I am very interested to extract more information from fish size data to be used for improving the data-poor stock assessment methods.

title: Nils Kruek
text:
Nils Kruek

Title


Senior Lecturer at IMAS studying marine population dynamics and data-poor fisheries. Nils is interested in a broad range of research projects on the ecology and management of marine species in Australia, southeast Asia and beyond. His primary area of expertise is area-based marine management, specifically the impacts of marine protected areas (MPAs) on both ecosystems and people. Over recent years, Nils has started working more intensively on size frequency distributions in natural and fished populations, and how a better understanding of size frequency distributions can help assess the status and appropriate management of data-poor fishery species.

title: Fish Size Project
text:
Our goals

Understand general properties of natural fish size frequency distributions
Explore how temperature affects fish sizes
Advance the use of novel data to assess fish populations
Improve size based methods and their applications to non traditional data
Incorporate historical records and oral histories in fish population status assessments
Develop a global map of human impacts on fish sizes
Promote sustainable fishing and restoration of fish size diversity

title: Fish Size Project
text:
Our mission

Humans have fished out most of the large fish. Climate change is also affecting fish sizes. Such changes to the natural fish population size structure impact fish population and ecosystem resilience. However, most fish populations are not assessed and humans impacts of fish size diversity loss remain undocumented.  We are using traditional and new sources of fish size data to understand how many small and large fish we should expect in natural populations, how fishing and warming are affecting these numbers and how we could restore what is lost.

title: Fish Size Project
text:

Conference session: Human impacts on fish and other marine organism body sizes, shifting baselines, and implications for ecosystems and fisheries

Join us at AMSA & NZMSS 2024 Conference in Hobart for a fascinating session exploring fish sizes and human impacts








Fish AI consortium monthly seminars

If you are interested in fish and AI, join monthly Fish AI consortrium monthly online seminars











Card game about sustainable fishing and marine literacy

We are launching a fun game Big Fish - will you catch the big fish or leave it to reproduce?

title: Fish Size Project
text:
Research





Properties of intra-specific size distributions
Are there general rules that govern species size distributions in natural populations? If so, we could use these rules to predict unfished size frequencies in nearly all fish species.
To date most analyses on fish size frequencies were conducted on commercially fished species, where fishing impacts have been extensive and long lasting. But new data sources, from underwater visual surveys, such as Reef Life Survey now provides opporunities to explore size distributions in hundreds of diverse and unfished species.








Temperature impacts on fish sizes
Temperature affects fish sizes, both naturally and through human induced climate change. Growth, mortality, reproduction and species composition are all affected by temperature. But what are the mechanisms and how do these temperature impacts manifest in natural populations, through space and time?
We use diverse data sources and simulations to explore temperature impacts on fish growth, size structure and population dynamics.








Applying size based models to assess human impacts
Size based models are a powerful tool to assess human impacts on fish populations. Traditionally these methods are used with catch data, but rapid accumulation of alternative data sources, such as visual census, citizen science, recreational fishing and underwater cameras, provide an opportunity to expand assessments across hundreds of fish species.
We are exploring best approaches to improve applications of size based population and community models to document human impacts in data poor fisheries and aquatic ecosystems in general.








Using historical records to understand shifting baselines
Historical records, such as old newspapers, logbooks, photos and archival records can provide valuable information about status of fish populations before detailed surveys began. These records are crucial to improve our understanding about natural fish sizes and address shifting baselines.
We are working with researches around the world to find new ways to use historical data in fish population assessments.

title: Fish Size Project
text:
Our Team















































Our core team is based at IMAS and CSIRO. We collaborate with many researchers at IMAS, in Australia and around the world and invite volunteering from students and the community.


Meet the team















































All underwater photography on this website was kindly provided by our team member Matt Testoni

title: Impact & Outreach
text:
Publications











Ecological consequences of body size decline in harvested fish species: positive feedback loops in trophic interactions amplify human impact

Asta Audzijonyte, Anna Kuparinen, Rebecca Gorton and Elizabeth A. Fulton
Biology Letters, 2013
Humans are changing marine ecosystems worldwide, both directly through fishing and indirectly through climate change. One of the little explored outcomes of human-induced change involves the decreasing body sizes of fishes. We use a marine ecosystem model to explore how a slow (less than 0.1% per year) decrease in the length of five harvested species could affect species interactions, biomasses and yields. We find that…
DOI: 10.1098/rsbl.2012.1103

title: Asta Audzijonyte
text:
Asta Audzijonyte

Lead Investigator


My goal is to understand and highlight human (fishing and climate change) impacts on fish size diversity and find solutions to restore fish populations with lots of big fish.

title: Carolina Chong-Montenegro
text:
Carolina Chong-Montenegro

Title


Fisheries ecologist whose research focuses on the use of archival sources and statistical modelling to reconstruct historical catch trends and evaluate the long-term effects of fishing on vulnerable fish populations. She is also interested in the evolutionary ecology of fish, in particular how fishing affects the population structure and size distribution of fish with complex life histories.

title: Sarah Willington
text:
Sarah Willington

Title


For my PhD, I am interested in looking at how fish size distributions are changing with ocean warming. My research uses simulation modelling to look at how changes in growth and mortality affect population size distributions, and comparing these changes to real fish population distributions to gain a better understanding of what is occurring in coastal rocky reef fishes.
